text:
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES,
No. 5
Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

(Drawing by Richard Graburn)

Please print name and address in capital letters.
Your full name ARTHUR R. DOHLEN
Present Address EARL GREY Sask
Pioneer Address EARL GREY Sask
Year you came to Saskatchewan 1905

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1914, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realize that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE.

NO. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

Please print name and address in capital letters.

Your full name: ARTHUR R DOHLEN
Present Address: EARL GREY, Sask.
Pioneer Address: EARL GREY, Sask.
Year you came to Saskatchewan: 1906

(Throughout the questionnaire, "Saskatchewan" means the area which is now Saskatchewan.)

PLEASE NOTE

This questionnaire is intended for persons who came to Saskatchewan before 1944, and most of the questions are about that early period, although in a few questions information for later years is asked for.

If you cannot answer a question, leave the space blank. We realise that any one person will not be able to answer all questions, so answer those that apply to your experience and that you can remember, and leave the others.

Use extra sheets of paper if there is not enough space on the questionnaire.

Your co-operation in answering this questionnaire will be very much appreciated, and all questionnaire files are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives as part of the permanent record of our province.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
NEIGHBORLY VISITING, PARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 10 or 12

How many of these were bachelor's homes? None

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday, or other days? Usually Sunday but often during the winter on any day.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Both

What time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually spent the day and often at night.

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes. Pioneers would never let a visitor go without a meal.

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (that is, was the term "take potluck" used, or was some other expression common?) No

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had "dropped in"? Coffee & cookies

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually someone stayed home as there were chores.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Usually a few quilting parties but no building "bees". Neighbors would help when anyone was building.

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the "bees" were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whist drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were "gatherings" in homes but little dancing for lack of space. Dancing came later when the town built a hall.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES.

No. 5

Pioneer Recreation and Social Life.

NEIGHBORLY VISITING, FARTIES, ETC.

1. In the first few years, how many homes were near enough to you for visiting back and forth? 10/12

How many of these were bachelor's homes? 7/12

2. How often did you usually visit neighbors?

3. Did you usually visit on a Sunday or other days? Usually Sunday but also during the week on any day.

4. Were you often invited to other homes, or was most visiting done without an invitation? Often

That time of the day did you go, - in the morning and spend the day, or in the afternoon, etc.? Usually spent the day and often a night

What about meals? Did you stay when not invited beforehand? Yes

How was the invitation to a meal worded when people had come unexpectedly? (Note: It seems there was no mention of this.)

Did it usually mean to "take potluck" used, or was some other expression employed? No

If no meal, what other refreshment might be offered to visitors who had dropped in? Coffee & cookies

5. Did the whole family go, or did someone stay home to "look after the place"? Usually someone stayed home on these visits.

6. Did you ever have "bees" when groups of neighbors came together to put up a building, make quilts, or other such activity? Usually

Tell what you remember about such gatherings, giving dates if possible, telling what the bees were for, and how often they occurred.

7. In the earliest years that you were here, were there many parties, whilst drives or dances in homes? Describe.

There were gatherings in homes but little dancing for lack of space. Dancing came later when the town built a hall.

Were these more frequent in later years? Give dates.

Did you follow any kind of informal schedule, such as going by turn from one home to another at definite times, - every two weeks, once a week, once a month, etc.? No
8. Tell what use was made of the school house for community dances, box socials and other activities. (Include also the school Christmas tree, picnics, etc., if you have not described these on the School Questionnaire). Give dates.

The school house was a community centre and was used for church services, political meetings, local club meetings (which during the '30s included an "Old Settler's Club"), School District meetings, box socials, concerts, plays (local) and of course dances.

How much of your social life was centred around the school, and within the school district? Describe.

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of? How large was it?

Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village/Talbot

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (for example, if you lived in the country, did you continue to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? We used both. The school continued to be the community social centre until into the '40s.

10. When parties, dances, etc. were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? Yes.

How were babies and small children provided for? They were usually put to sleep in a bedroom. After they slept on a blanket on the school stage.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Yes.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist, Norwegian whist, Poker - Bridge came later.

Was there card playing for a prize? Not usually.

What dances were popular? Waltz, square.

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. None that I remember.

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
8. Tell what was made of the school house for community dances, box socials, and other activities. (Include also the school board, school grounds, etc.)

9. When was your first community hall built?

What material was it made of?
Who built it - the community through special funds, the municipality, some organization, etc.?

Was it built in the village or town, or was it a country hall? Village/Town

To what extent did it take the place of homes or the school house as a place for social gatherings and parties? (For example, if you lived in the country, did you ever have to use the local school house for district gatherings, and come to the hall in town for other functions, or were you close enough to make use of the hall for all gatherings, etc.? We used both. The school continued to be the community social center until the 40's.

10. When parties, dances, etc., were held in homes, school houses or halls (as referred to in question 8, 9, and 10) did the entire family attend? They were usually just to stay in a bedroom when they adjourned to the hall.

How were tables and small children provided for? They were usually set up in the hall.

How were horses sheltered and fed in the winter time at these parties? Yes.

11. What card games were popular in the early days? Whist, Rummy, Poker

Was there card playing for a prize? No

What dances were popular? Waltz, Square

Was there ever any disagreement between dancing and non-dancing residents in the planning of parties and social gatherings? Explain. None

Was card playing accepted by all residents in the community, or were there some who frowned upon it, either as an entertainment in the home, or for community gatherings? Explain.
12. What attempts at formality, or "swank", do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially—in parlor, etc.?  
There was none of this around this district.

13. Was the chivaree known in your community?  
Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.  
Chivarees were never done in this community.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS.

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember becoming established in your community?  
Give the date and reason for it being organized.

16. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community?  
Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.  
I don't remember it being organized. I joined the Gibbs local in 1918.  
Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?  
No rec.  
How many women belonged? None  
How often did it meet? Monthly  
What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? No  
When was it organized?  
Approximately how many women belonged to it?  
Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
12. What attempts at formality, or "snobbery," do you remember in small towns, such as gloves and hats when calling, calling cards, visitors treated ceremonially, etc.? 

13. Was the chivaree known in your community? Describe what you remember about chivarees, telling how common they were, any incidents connected with them, etc.

14. Describe any other details of visiting, parties, etc., that you remember, telling of any games or amusements not already mentioned that were popular at parties and give approximate dates whenever you can when some changes in visiting or social life became noticeable.

ORGANIZATIONS AND MEETINGS:

15. What was the name of the first organization of any kind that you can remember being established in your community? Give the date and reason for it being organized.

26. Was there a Saskatchewan Grain Growers local in your community? Tell when it was organized, and what steps led to its organization.

Approximately what proportion of the farmers in the community belonged to it?

How many women belonged? How often did it meet? What were some of the activities carried on by this organization?

17. Was there a Homemakers' Club in your district? When was it organized? Approximately how many women belonged to it? Describe what you remember of its activities and services.
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, date when it was first organized, its activities and purposes, who belonged (men, women, young people?), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centred in the town or village and included the surrounding community. (There is space in the church questionnaire for organizations connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.? Describe, telling who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible. Who provided the lantern and the slides? What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (-mumbletypeg, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (-skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
18. Name any other organizations that were in existence in your community before 1914, giving the name of each, dates when it was first organized, its activities, its purposes, who belonged (men only, women only, young people only), whether it included people only in one relatively small area (for example, within a school district), or was centered in the town or village (for example, included the surrounding community). (There is space in the church quire and included the surrounding connected with the church, so they need not be included here).

What means were commonly used by organizations for raising money?

19. Where did various organizations hold their meetings?

20. Were you accustomed to having general information lectures, talks on foreign lands, etc.,? Who gave them (local ministers or teachers, special lecturers, etc.), where they were held, how well they were attended, and any other details you remember about them.

Did you often have magic lantern shows? Give dates if possible.

Who provided the lantern and the slides?

What were the slides about?

CHILDREN'S GAMES

21. What games did boys play in summer (marbletopping, ball, marbles, fly kites, etc.)?

What games did girls play in summer (skipping rope, play house, etc.)?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games?

Did the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, arrowheads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS.

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? Give year and month if possible. 1906 July 4

26. Who organized it? Local farmers

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? For the community

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Dancing on a platform (fiddle music)

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? General lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time of the day did it start, and how long did it last?
22. What winter games were played outside - fox and hounds, skating, etc.? 

What games were played indoors in winter - card games such as "Happy Families", "Authors" or others, checkers or other games? 

Was the whole family join in such games, or only the children? Explain.

23. Was there much time for games, or was everyone usually busy with some kind of work? Explain.

24. Did children invent games connected with such things as buffalo bones, antelope heads, gophers or other objects or animals, or games in the snow? Describe.

PICNICS AND SPORTS,

25. What was the date of the first picnic that you attended in Saskatchewan? 
Give year and month if possible. 1906 July

26. Who organized it? Local farmers

27. Was it for the entire community, or for a smaller group, such as a school district, Sunday school, some organization, etc.? 
for the community

28. Was it the first picnic held in the community? 
If not, do you know the date of the first one that had been held?

29. What were the amusements at the picnic you attended (ball games, races, band, etc.)? Dancing on a platform (fiddle music)

30. What arrangements were made for eating - was there a general lunch, or did families and friends form smaller groups? 
General lunch

31. What did you have to eat and drink?

32. What time or the day did it start, and how long did it last?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday School picnics, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

For many years there was a "Scotch" picnic held on the Renwick farm near Gibbs that was the most popular event of the summer. These picnics included races, horseshoe pitching, nail diving contests, ball games, waltzing contests and a "sit down supper" (which was, of course, pot luck).

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year? How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities - played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centres, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
33. Describe any features of this picnic which you remember as outstanding.

34. Describe any different kinds of picnics which you knew of in the early days, such as the large community picnic, school or Sunday school picnic, family picnics, etc. Tell about any differences in numbers attending, activities, food and drink, when held, etc.

35. What changes have you noticed in picnics since the first years? If possible, give dates when changes became noticeable.

36. Describe the sports which were popular in your community in the early years, telling who took part in the various games and sports (men, women, mostly young people).

37. For what game was the first team organized in your community to play against neighboring teams?

What year?

How long did it continue?

38. Name any other sports teams that were organized before 1914, giving date of organization if possible, and tell something of their activities—played against teams from neighboring towns, played at local sports days, entered in competitions in larger centers, etc.

39. Tell when the first outdoor rink was built in your community, and what it was used for (hockey, curling, etc.).

When was the first indoor rink built, and what was it used for?
40. When did an annual "sports day" become established in your community?
   Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community picnic?
   Who was responsible for starting the first sports day?

   When was the sports day usually held? (what month, or any special day, such as May 24th or July 1st).

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the names and authors if possible. If not, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them?
   What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun?
   To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school text books as additional reading material?
7.

40. Then did an annual "sports day" become established in your community? Did it grow out of or replace the earlier community plans? Who was responsible for starting the first sports day? What was the sports day usually called (what month, or any special days, such as May 24th or July 1st)?

41. Are there any from your community who have become members of well-known hockey, ball or other teams? Give names, and dates.

READING

42. What books did you bring with you when you came west? (Give a list of the titles and authors. If possible, tell as nearly as you can how many books you brought, and what kind.) (Use extra sheets if necessary)

43. How many of your neighbors brought books with them? What kind of books and how many?

44. To what extent did you exchange books with neighbors?

45. Did you buy many books after you came west? Give details.

46. What books were sent to you as gifts in early years?

47. Have you ever had any "travelling library" books in your community or school? Give details and dates.

48. Was there a school library? When was it begun? To what extent were books borrowed from the school library for adults to read at home?

49. Did parents ever use their children's school texts books as additional reading material?
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? No

When was it started?

Who started it?

Is it still in existence?

If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library - how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material?

Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
50. Has there ever been a community library in your district or town? Yes

When was it started? Who started it?

Is it still in existence? If not, when was it discontinued, and why?

Give any other details which you can about the library—how many books it contained, how many people used it, where it was kept, who acted as librarian, and what arrangements were made for borrowing books.

51. What newspapers or magazines did you subscribe to when you first came to the west?

52. Describe later changes in your subscriptions, telling why you stopped certain subscriptions and added others.

53. Did you ever obtain the free monthly Lady Aberdeen packages of reading material? Give dates and tell how and where you got them.

54. What books or papers that you brought to the west with you do you still have?

55. Did you find a lack of reading material or sources of information in your early days in the west a hardship? Explain.
MUSICAL ENTERTAINMENT.

56. What musical instruments did you bring west with you? [violin]

57. What instruments did any of your neighbors have?

58. What musical instruments have you bought since you came to the west? Give dates, prices if possible, and tell where you bought them.
   [piano 1923 no recollection price]
   [organ 1941]

59. How large a part did singing and other forms of music play in your home entertainment in early years in the West? Describe.

in the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

60. What were some of the favorite songs in the home?
   in the community?

61. Was "folk music", or music of the country you came from, popular in your home or community? Explain.

62. Did you ever make up any of your own songs, or make up words to fit an old tune as a joke on somebody, or because of some special happening in the community? Explain.

63. Was there a band in your community? When was it started?
   Who started it? How long did it continue?
   How many were in it? Who was bandmaster?
   What instruments were included?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where, if members had uniforms, what events the band played for.

Musical Instrumentation:

In the community? (were there musical concerts, was there group singing at parties, etc.) Describe.

In the community?

Tell what you remember of its activities, how often practice was held, where,

If members had uniforms, what events the band played for.
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. Is music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

Our collection - muzzle loaders
muskets
rifles
shotguns

arrowheads
Indian hammers

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.

68. Describe other hobbies or special interests of yours not already mentioned.

69. Is there anyone in your community who is well-known for any of these hobbies, or for others such as photography, bird-watching, etc.?

GENERAL

70. Describe any outstanding features or incidents of social life, games, entertainment, sports, reading, music of pioneer days, not already mentioned. (Use back of page, or extra sheets if necessary).
64. Has anyone from your community become well known or famous in the musical world? Give names and dates and places of public appearances.

65. In music as important or less important in your community now as compared with the early days? What is the reason for this change?

HOBBIES AND SPECIAL INTERESTS.

66. Do you have any "collections", such as stamps, stones, paintings, signatures, arrowheads, etc.? Give details of this collection, telling when you started it, how you became interested in it, any outstanding events connected with it, and a description of the collection.

67. Did you make notes of the weather, time of arrival of birds, blooming time of trees, etc.? Explain.
